summary: Email correspondence between prosecutors and defense attorney Suzanne Jaffe Bloom regarding a grand jury subpoena issued to an unnamed client, discussing scheduling, provision of court transcripts, and the existence of telephone records showing contacts with underage girls.

persons.name: Suzanne Jaffe Bloom
persons.context: Partner at Winston & Strawn LLP representing an unnamed client who received a grand jury subpoena; she is coordinating with prosecutors regarding scheduling and information sharing.

persons.name: Johanna Rae Hudgens
persons.context: Copied on the email correspondence between the prosecutors and Suzanne Jaffe Bloom regarding the grand jury subpoena and related scheduling.

connections.description: Both are involved in legal correspondence regarding a grand jury subpoena, with Bloom representing a client and Hudgens being part of the prosecutorial team.

events.title: Grand Jury Subpoena Issued
events.description: SDNY grand jury subpoena was issued to an unnamed client of Suzanne Jaffe Bloom.

events.title: Original Grand Jury Appearance Date
events.description: The grand jury appearance date listed in the subpoena, which was adjourned and no appearance was required.

events.title: Proposed Meeting Date
events.description: Suzanne Jaffe Bloom proposed a meeting with prosecutors at 2 pm on this date.

locations: 200 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10166-4193 (Winston & Strawn LLP office)
Florida (mentioned in context of federal court cases involving Mr. Epstein)
keyFacts: Prosecutors possess contemporaneous telephone records, including from a cell phone registered to the unnamed client, showing numerous phone contacts with multiple girls who were underage at the time of the calls.
The grand jury appearance date of July 24, 2019, for the subpoenaed client was adjourned and held in abeyance.
Several civil case docket numbers related to Jeffrey Epstein are referenced: 15 Civ. 7433 (RWS) (SDNY), 17 Civ. 616 (JGK) (SDNY), and 08 Civ. 80736 (SDFL) (the CVRA litigation).
The correspondence involves scheduling a meeting and sharing information like court transcripts and a standard proffer agreement example.
The client's identity is not disclosed in the text, but they are the subject of a grand jury subpoena and possess phone records linking them to underage girls.
